content.p: Suppose a factory intends to manufacture cardboard crates. The crates will be in the shape of a rectangular prism{{topQ}} Due to constraints in the infrastructure of the factory, the height of the crate must equal the length of one of the sides of the base. Further, they must use {{A}} square inches of material for each crate. Given these contraints, what is the maximum volume for such a crate?
**note** This solves the problem: "given a limit on our material, how do we maximize our carrying capacity?"

Suppose a factory intends to manufacture sheet metal crates. The crates will be in the shape of a rectangular prism{{topQ}} Due to constraints imposed by their client, the length of the base of a crate must be {{c}} times the width of the base. Further, the volume of a crate must be {{V0}} feet^3. Given these constraints, what is the minimum surface area of such a crate?
**note** This solves the problem: "given that we must carry (at least) a certain level of capacity, how do we minimize our material used (or equivalently, our cost)?"
